existing_events.name: Henry Miller was born
existing_events.description: Henry Valentine Miller was born on December 26 in New York City.

existing_events.name: Family moved to Brooklyn
existing_events.description: Miller's family moved to 1063 Decatur Street in Brooklyn's Bushwick neighborhood.

existing_events.name: Henry Miller was active with the Socialist Party of America
existing_events.description: Miller was active with the Socialist Party of America.

existing_events.name: Attended Eastern District High School
existing_events.description: Miller attended Eastern District High School in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, after finishing elementary school.

existing_events.name: Attended City College of New York
existing_events.description: Miller attended the City College of New York for one semester.

existing_events.name: Henry Miller married Beatrice Sylvas Wickens
existing_events.description: Miller married Beatrice Sylvas Wickens, an amateur pianist.

existing_events.name: Daughter Barbara born
existing_events.description: Miller and Beatrice had a daughter named Barbara.

existing_events.name: Worked at Western Union
existing_events.description: Miller worked at Western Union as personnel manager in the messenger department.

existing_events.name: Wrote first novel Clipped Wings
existing_events.description: Miller wrote his first novel, 'Clipped Wings,' during a three-week vacation in March (unpublished, only fragments remain).

existing_events.name: Divorced Beatrice Sylvas Wickens
existing_events.description: Miller was divorced from Beatrice Sylvas Wickens.

existing_events.name: Met June Mansfield
existing_events.description: Miller met and became enamored of June Mansfield (born Juliet Edith Smerth) at a dance hall.

existing_events.name: Married June Mansfield
existing_events.description: Miller married June Mansfield.

existing_events.name: Quit Western Union to write
existing_events.description: Miller quit his job at Western Union to dedicate himself completely to writing.

existing_events.name: Wrote Moloch
existing_events.description: Miller wrote 'Moloch: or, This Gentile World,' initially under the guise of a novel by June Mansfield (unpublished until 1992).

existing_events.name: Spent months in Paris with June
existing_events.description: Miller spent several months in Paris with June, trip financed by Roland Freedman.

existing_events.name: Moved to Paris alone
existing_events.description: Miller moved to Paris unaccompanied.

existing_events.name: Proofreader for Chicago Tribune Paris
existing_events.description: Miller was employed by the Chicago Tribune Paris edition as a proofreader.

existing_events.name: Published Tropic of Cancer
existing_events.description: Miller's first published book, 'Tropic of Cancer,' was published by Obelisk Press (banned in the United States).

existing_events.name: Divorced by June in Mexico
existing_events.description: June divorced Miller by proxy.

existing_events.name: Published Black Spring
existing_events.description: Miller published 'Black Spring' (banned in the United States).

existing_events.name: Published Tropic of Capricorn
existing_events.description: Miller published 'Tropic of Capricorn' (banned in the United States).

existing_events.name: Visited Greece
existing_events.description: Miller visited Greece, invited by Lawrence Durrell who was living in Corfu.

existing_events.name: Returned to New York
existing_events.description: Miller returned to New York.

existing_events.name: Published The Colossus of Maroussi
existing_events.description: Miller described his visit to Greece in 'The Colossus of Maroussi'.

existing_events.name: Moved to California
existing_events.description: Miller moved to California in June, initially residing just outside Hollywood in Beverly Glen.

existing_events.name: Began writing Sexus
existing_events.description: Miller began writing 'Sexus,' the first novel in 'The Rosy Crucifixion' trilogy.

existing_events.name: Settled in Big Sur
existing_events.description: Miller settled in Big Sur.

existing_events.name: Married Janina Martha Lepska
existing_events.description: Miller married Janina Martha Lepska.

existing_events.name: Published Sunday After the War
existing_events.description: Miller published 'Sunday After the War'.

existing_events.name: Published The Air-Conditioned Nightmare
existing_events.description: Miller published 'The Air-Conditioned Nightmare'.

existing_events.name: Lived in Big Sur with bohemian writers
existing_events.description: Miller continued living in Big Sur with other bohemian writers.

existing_events.name: Divorced Janina Martha Lepska
existing_events.description: Miller was divorced from Janina Martha Lepska.

existing_events.name: Married artist Eve McClure
existing_events.description: Miller married artist Eve McClure.

existing_events.name: Published Big Sur and the Oranges of Hieronymus Bosch
existing_events.description: Miller published 'Big Sur and the Oranges of Hieronymus Bosch'.

existing_events.name: Completed The Rosy Crucifixion trilogy
existing_events.description: Miller completed 'The Rosy Crucifixion' trilogy (initially banned in the U.S., published in France and Japan).

existing_events.name: Divorced Eve McClure
existing_events.description: Miller was divorced from Eve McClure.

existing_events.name: Reunion with June in New York
existing_events.description: Miller arranged a reunion with ex-wife June in New York.

existing_events.name: Tropic of Cancer published in the US
existing_events.description: 'Tropic of Cancer' was published in the United States by Grove Press, leading to obscenity trials.

existing_events.name: Moved to Pacific Palisades
existing_events.description: Miller moved to 444 Ocampo Drive, Pacific Palisades, Los Angeles.

existing_events.name: Married Hiroko Tokuda
existing_events.description: Miller married Hiroko Tokuda.

existing_events.name: Published On Turning Eighty
existing_events.description: Miller published 'On Turning Eighty,' a chapbook with 200 copies.

existing_events.name: Nominated for Nobel Prize
existing_events.description: Miller was nominated for the Nobel Prize in Literature by University of Copenhagen professor Allan Philip.

existing_events.name: Divorced Hiroko Tokuda
existing_events.description: Miller was divorced from Hiroko Tokuda.

existing_events.name: Henry Miller died
existing_events.description: Henry Miller died of circulatory complications at home.

url_events_summarized: Henry Valentine Miller was born at his family's home, 450 East 85th Street, in the Yorkville section of Manhattan, New York City, U.S. He was the son of Lutheran German parents, Louise Marie (Neiting) and tailor Heinrich Miller. Miller attended Eastern District High School in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, after finishing elementary school While he was a socialist, his idol was the black Socialist Hubert Harrison Miller married his first wife, Beatrice Sylvas Wickens, in 1917;[11] their divorce was granted on December 21, 1923.[12] Together they had a daughter, Barbara, born in 1919
